questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with difficulty chewing and numbness on the right side of his jaw following a recent sports injury. Examination reveals weakened jaw clenching on the right and decreased sensation over the anterior cheek, but intact sensation in the lower lip. Which of the following nerves might be affected?
questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior division of mandibular nerve

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not receive motor fibers from the nucleus ambiguus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:D) Trigeminal nerve (V)

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with unilateral facial pain and sensory loss on the left side of her face. Examination reveals that she cannot feel light touch, pain, or temperature on the left side, but her corneal reflex remains intact. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?

options.label: C
options.text: Lesion of right spinal trigeminal nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: Lesion of left spinal trigeminal nucleus

questions.correct_answer: D. Lesion of left spinal trigeminal nucleus
questions.explanation:
Nucleus

Location

Function

Mesencephalic Nucleus

Midbrain

Proprioception (position sense) of muscles of mastication and jaw.
 

  • A lesion here would affect the jaw-jerk reflex.

Main Sensory Nucleus

Pons

Mediates tactile (light touch) and pressure sensations from the face.

Spinal Trigeminal Nucleus

Extends from the pons to the spinal cord.

Handles pain and temperature sensations from the face.

Motor Nucleus

Pons

Controls muscles involved in chewing (mastication).

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly distinguishes the role of the hypoglossal nerve from the olfactory nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the muscles of the tongue, while the olfactory nerve mediates smell via the thalamus.

options.label: B
options.text: The hypoglossal nerve is involved in motor control of the tongue, while the olfactory nerve mediates smell without synapsing in the thalamus.

options.label: C
options.text: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the tongue and is part of the olfactory pathway.

options.label: D
options.text: Both the hypoglossal and olfactory nerves are involved in taste and smell.

questions.correct_answer: B. The hypoglossal nerve is involved in motor control of the tongue, while the olfactory nerve mediates smell without synapsing in the thalamus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Physical examination reveals a diminished gag reflex and weakened pharyngeal elevation during swallowing. Which of the following structures is not innervated by the affected nerve?
questions.explanation:
Fibers

Function

Nucleus

Special Visceral Efferent

Supplies Stylopharyngeus muscle

Nucleus Ambiguous

General Visceral Efferent

Secretomotor innervation to the Parotid gland

Inferior Salivatory Nucleus.

Special Visceral Afferent

Taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue (including vallate papillae)

Nucleus Tractus Solitarius.

General Visceral Afferent

Carry pain, touch, and temperature sensations from the pharynx, tonsils, soft palate, and posterior one-third of the tongue

Dorsal Nucleus of the Vagus.

General Somatic Afferent

Carry proprioceptive sensations from the stylopharyngeus muscle and skin of the auricle.

Spinal Nucleus of the Trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with difficulty swallowing and a hoarse voice after recent neck surgery. What structure does the vagus nerve primarily run between as it descends in the neck?

options.label: A
options.text: Internal carotid artery and external jugular vein

options.label: B
options.text: Internal jugular vein and common carotid artery

options.label: C
options.text: Subclavian artery and internal thoracic artery

options.label: D
options.text: External carotid artery and internal jugular vein

questions.correct_answer: B. Internal jugular vein and common carotid artery

questions.text: A 38-year-old female with down-out and intorsion of the eye presents with worsening night vision, occasional headaches, and mild dizziness. Examination shows ptosis and a larger, non-reactive left pupil. Which of the following structures is the parasympathetic component of the affected nerve?
questions.explanation:
Oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III)

Type

Motor

Origin

Midbrain (Oculomotor sulcus on the medial aspect of the cerebral peduncle).

Course

 

Components

Oculomotor nucleus (somatic component) (Option B):

General somatic efferent (GSE) fibres emerge from this site and supply -

  • Superior division:
    • Levator palpebrae superioris
    • Superior rectus
  • Inferior division:
    • Medial rectus
    • Inferior rectus
    • Inferior oblique

Edinger-Westphal nucleus (parasympathetic component) (Option A):

General visceral efferent (GVE) fibres arise from this site and supply:

  • Sphincter pupillae
  • Ciliaris

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with facial asymmetry and difficulty smiling. Upon examination, the physician suspects a lesion affecting the facial nerve.Where does the facial nerve divide into its five terminal branches within the parotid gland?

options.label: B
options.text: Behind the neck of the mandible

options.label: C
options.text: Near the spine of the sphenoid

questions.correct_answer: B. Behind the neck of the mandible

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with sharp, shooting pain and numbness in her forehead, upper eyelid, upper face, upper lip, and part of her cheek after a recent car accident. She has a diminished corneal reflex on the right side. Which divisions of the trigeminal nerve are affected?
questions.explanation:
Ophthalmic division (V1)

Maxillary division (V2)

Mandibular division (V3)

Type

Sensory

Sensory

Mixed

Course

Branches

Frontal

  • Supratrochlear
  • Supraorbital

Nasociliary

  • Branch to the ciliary ganglion
  • 2–3 long ciliary nerves
  • Posterior ethmoidal
  • Infratrochlear
  • Anterior ethmoidal

Lacrimal: Branch to the upper eyelid and secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland.
  • Infraorbital
  • Zygomaticofacial
  • Zygomaticotemporal
  • Mental
  • Buccal
  • Auriculo-temporal

Supply

  • Forehead
  • Upper eyelids
  • Root of nose
  • Tip of nose
  • Frontal air sinus
  • Scalp
  • Lower eyelids
  • Lateral sides of the nose
  • Upper lip
  • Cheek (upper part)
  • Anterior part of the temporal region
  • Lower lip
  • Chin
  • Lower teeth
  • Lower part of the cheek
  • Lateral side (Upper 2/3rd) of auricle, temporal region

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with drooping of her left eyelid, double vision, and a dilated, fixed left pupil. She also reports difficulty focusing on close objects and some mild forward projection of her left eye. Neurological examination reveals that the left eye is turned downward and outward. A CT scan shows no evidence of mass lesions or hemorrhage.Which of the following is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
Identify the structure marked with the arrow and select which nerve root arises from it.
Which of the following cranial nerves is not involved in the Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) pathway?
Which of the following correctly describes the arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei from ventral to dorsal in the brainstem?

options.label: A
options.text: General Visceral Efferent (GVE), General Visceral Afferent (GVA), Special Visceral Afferent (SVA), Special Somatic Afferent (SSA).

options.label: B
options.text: General Somatic Afferent (GSA), Special Somatic Afferent (SSA), General Visceral Efferent (GVE), General Somatic Efferent (GSE).

options.label: C
options.text: General Somatic Efferent (GSE), Special Visceral Efferent (SVE), General Visceral Efferent (GVE), General Somatic Afferent (GSA).

options.label: D
options.text: Special Visceral Afferent (SVA), Special Somatic Afferent (SSA), General Somatic Efferent (GSE), General Visceral Afferent (GVA).

questions.correct_answer: A. General Visceral Efferent (GVE), General Visceral Afferent (GVA), Special Visceral Afferent (SVA), Special Somatic Afferent (SSA).

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents with double vision and difficulty moving his left eye outward. Examination reveals the left eye is deviated medially with limited abduction. Which muscle is involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Abducens Nerve (cranial nerve VI)

Type

Motor

Origin

Pons (lower border, opposite the pyramid of the medulla).

Course

 


 

Functional component
  • General somatic efferent fibres: Arise from the abducent nucleus in the pons and supply the lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball.
  • General somatic afferent fibres carry proprioceptive sensations from the lateral rectus and terminate in the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

Supply

Lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball

Clinical aspect

Lesion or injury (elevated intracranial pressure) of the abducens nerve results in paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to:

  • Inability to abduct the eye
  • Diplopia (double vision)
  • Convergent squint (due to the unopposed action of medial rectus) (Option B)

questions.text: Below is an image of a transverse section of the lower pons, specifically at the level of the facial colliculus. Please identify the structures marked as "X" and "Y."
questions.correct_answer: A. Abducens nucleus and Facial nucleus

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents with a head tilt and double vision that worsens when looking down, especially while reading or using his phone. Examination shows a significant limitation in the left eye's downward movement, extorsion of the eyeball, and a noticeable right head tilt. At what site does the decussation of the affected nerve occur?
questions.explanation:
Trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV)

Type

Motor

Origin

Dorsal aspect of the midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus

Special features

  • The only cranial nerve which emerges on the dorsal aspect of the brain.
  • The most slender nerve of all the cranial nerves.
  • The smallest cranial nerve.
  • Only cranial nerve whose nuclear fibres decussate before emerging on the surface of the brain.
  • Nucleus receives only ipsilateral corticonuclear fibres.
  • Phylogenetically, it is the nerve of the 3rd eye.

Course

 


 

Nuclei

Trochlear nucleus is situated in the ventromedial part of the central grey matter in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus.

Supply

Superior oblique muscle of the eyeball.

Clinical aspect

Trochlear nerve lesions/injury causes paralysis of the superior oblique muscle, presenting clinically as:

  • Extorsion of the eyeball and weakness of downward gaze (difficulty while going downstairs or reading the newspaper)
  • Diplopia (double vision) occurs when the patient looks laterally and glances downward (there is a compensatory head tilt to the opposite side).

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with diabetes arrives at the emergency department with sudden right-sided weakness and trouble speaking. His examination shows left-sided ptosis, the left eye in a "down and out" position, and right-sided paralysis of the lower face. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 50-year-old patient experiences numbness in the area around the neck following a cervical block performed for neck surgery. Which of the following is not a branch of the cervical plexus?

options.label: B
options.text: Transverse Cutaneous Nerve of the Neck

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with difficulty swallowing and changes in voice quality. Upon examination, the physician suspects a neurological issue affecting the muscles of the larynx and pharynx. Which nucleus is responsible for the motor innervation of these muscles?
questions.explanation:
Functional Column

Function

Nucleus

Special Visceral Efferent

Supply muscles of the palate, pharynx, and larynx

Nucleus Ambiguus

General Visceral Efferent

Parasympathetic innervation to the heart, bronchial tree, and GIT

Dorsal Nucleus of the Vagus

(Option A)

Special Visceral Afferent

Taste sensations from the posterior part of the tongue and epiglottis

Nucleus Tractus Solitarius

(Option C)

General Visceral Afferent

Convey sensations from the mucous membranes of the pharynx, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and thoracic/abdominal viscera

Nucleus Tractus Solitarius & Dorsal Nucleus of Vagus

General Somatic Afferent

Carry sensations from the skin of the Auricle

Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve (Option D)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient experiences redness and sweating in the right cheek while eating. Which of the following components is directly involved in the aberrant nerve regeneration causing these symptoms?

A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty swallowing and loss of taste sensation from the posterior third of his tongue. On examination, there is a loss of the gag reflex on the right side. Further tests reveal decreased salivary secretion from the parotid gland. Given the clinical findings, which of the following structures is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Glossopharyngeal nerve

Category

Details

Origin
  • Arises from the brainstem.
  • Nuclei involved:
    • Nucleus ambiguus: Motor fibres.
    • Inferior salivatory nucleus: Parasympathetic fibers.

Pathway/Exit
  • Travels between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein.
  • Exits the skull via the jugular foramen.

Course
  • Parasympathetic fibres travel via the lesser petrosal nerve.
  • Synapse in the otic ganglion.
  • Postganglionic fibres from the otic ganglion innervate the parotid gland.

Motor Supply
  • Innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle.
  • Function: Elevates the pharynx during swallowing.

Sensory Supply
  • Sensory innervation to the posterior third of the tongue (taste and general sensation).
  • Sensory innervation to the pharynx (necessary for the gag reflex).

Parasympathetic Supply
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland.
  • Function: Salivation from the parotid gland.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with difficulty in smiling and closing eyelids on the right side. The patient does not have any history of recent trauma or infections. The image below shows the patient's face. Sensory function, including taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and sensation to light touch, appears intact. Which nerve column is primarily responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Nerve Column

Nucleus Origin

Function

Special Visceral Afferent

Nucleus Solitarius

Carries taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue via the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

General Visceral Efferent

Superior salivatory nucleus

Parasympathetic innervation to glands (lacrimal, submandibular, sublingual).

Special Visceral Efferent

Facial nucleus in the pons

Innervates muscles derived from branchial (pharyngeal) arches.

General Somatic Afferent

Geniculate ganglion

Carries sensory information from the skin (e.g., touch, pain).

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with excessive tearing while eating, which started a few months ago. Upon further questioning, she recalls having facial nerve palsy about a year ago, which has since improved. Based on this presentation, at what level of the facial nerve pathway did the injury most likely occur?

options.label: A
options.text: At the level of the geniculate ganglion

options.label: B
options.text: At the level of the chorda tympani

options.label: D
options.text: At the level of the greater petrosal nerve

questions.correct_answer: A. At the level of the geniculate ganglion
questions.explanation:
Course of Facial Nerve

Segment

Description

Clinical Significance (Topodiagnostic tests help in determining the location of facial nerve lesion)

Intracranial (Cisternal)

Emerges from the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction, medial to CN VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve).

Lesions can cause facial weakness or paralysis.

Intratemporal

Meatal Segment

It enters the internal acoustic meatus with CN VIII and the nervus intermedius.

Vulnerable to compression in acoustic neuromas.

Labyrinthine Segment (Most common site for facial nerve palsy.)

Extends from the internal acoustic meatus to the geniculate ganglion; limited blood supply.

Damage can affect taste and hearing.

Tympanic Segment

Runs horizontally through the middle ear cavity above the oval window and stapes.

Injury in this segment may lead to altered middle ear function and hearing.

Mastoid Segment

Longest segment; descends vertically through the mastoid bone, giving off branches like the nerve to stapedius and chorda tympani (anterior 2/3 tongue)

Injury can lead to facial nerve dysfunction, including Bell's palsy.

Extratemporal

Stylomastoid Foramen

It exits the skull and enters the parotid gland.

Damage here leads to facial muscle weakness but spares glands and taste.

Parotid gland

Divides into temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical branches to innervate facial muscles.

  • The nerve passes through but does not innervate the parotid.

Facial nerve injury during parotid surgery causes facial paralysis.

Topodiagnostic tests

Key points

Schirmer test

Decreased lacrimation indicates a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion.

Stapedial reflex

It is lost in lesions above the nerve to stapedius.

Taste test

Impairment of taste indicates a lesion above the chorda tympani.

Submandibular salivary flow test

Decreased salivation shows injury above the chorda tympani.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with difficulty chewing and pain near his temporomandibular joint (TMJ) after sustaining blunt trauma to the side of his face. Upon examination, there is tenderness over the ramus of the mandible. Which muscle is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Muscles of mandible

Muscle

Location

Action

Nerve Supply

Masseter

Covers the ramus of the mandible

Elevates the mandible for biting and chewing

 

 

Mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3)

Temporalis

Attached to the coronoid process

Elevates and retracts the mandible

Lateral Pterygoid

Located in the infratemporal fossa

Protracts and depresses the mandible and moves it laterally.

Medial Pterygoid

It runs parallel to the masseter on the inner side of the ramus of mandible.

Elevates and assists in protrusion of the mandible

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with difficulty opening his mouth following a jaw injury. Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for opening the mouth?
questions.explanation:
Principal muscles

Accessory muscles
  • Temporalis
  • Masseter
  • Lateral pterygoid
  • Medial pterygoid
  • Digastric
  • Buccinator
  • Mylohyoid
  • Geniohyoid.

 

Origin

Insertion

Nerve supply

Action

Masseter

(Option A)

Superficial layer (largest): Zygomatic arch (anterior 2/3rds of the lower border) and adjoining zygomatic process.

 

Middle layer: Zygomatic arch (lower border of posterior 1/3rd).

 

Deep layer: Zygomatic arch (deep) surface.

Superficial layer:

Ramus of the mandible (lower part of lateral surface).

 

Middle layer:

Ramus of mandible (central part).

 

Deep layer:

Ramus of the mandible (rest of the part)

Masseteric nerve (Anterior division of mandibular nerve)
  • Elevates the mandible (close the mouth).
  • Protrusion

Temporalis

(Option B)

  • Temporal fossa (excluding zygomatic bone)
  • Temporal fascia
  • Coronoid process
  • Ramus of mandible (anterior border).

Deep temporal nerves (Anterior division of mandibular nerve)
  • Elevates mandible (close the mouth)
  • Side-to-side (grinding) movement
  • Retraction of mandible

Lateral pterygoid

(Option D)

Upper head (smaller): Infratemporal surface and crest of greater wing (sphenoid bone)

 

Lower head (larger): lateral pterygoid plate (lateral surface)
  • Pterygoid fovea (neck of mandible)
  • Articular disc (anterior margin) and capsule of temporomandibular joint

A branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve
  • Depresses mandible (open the mouth)
  • Protrusion
  • Turns chin to the opposite side (right lateral pterygoid turns chin to left)

Medial pterygoid

(Option C)

Superficial head: tuberosity of maxilla and adjoining bone

 

Deep head: lateral pterygoid plate (medial surface) and adjoining surface of palatine bone

Angle (rough area on the medial surface) and adjoining ramus of the mandible.

Nerve to medial pterygoid (main trunk of the mandibular nerve)
  • Elevates the mandible (close the mouth)
  • Protrusion
  • Grinding movement

questions.text: A 48-year-old female with diabetes presents with severe, sharp right-sided facial pain triggered by light touch, along with numbness and tingling. Examination shows hyperesthesia and decreased sensation on the right side. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Spinal nucleus of Vth nerve

(Option A)

Principal sensory nucleus of Vth nerve (Option D)

Mesencephalic nucleus

(Option C)

Fibers conveying pain and temperature sensations from the majority of the facial area synapse at this location.

Fibers transmitting touch and pressure sensations synapse in this nucleus

This nucleus extends into the midbrain and receives proprioceptive impulses from the muscles of mastication, the temporomandibular joint, and the teeth.

Motor nucleus of the Vth nerve

(Option B)

These fibres supply the muscles derived from the first pharyngeal arch, namely the muscles of mastication, the mylohyoid, the anterior belly of the digastric, the tensor palatini and the tensor tympani.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with sudden numbness, tingling, heaviness, dull pain, and heightened sensitivity on the right side of her face. Examination shows reduced sensation in the right maxillary and mandibular areas, with intact motor function and no other deficits. From which location does the affected cranial nerve emerge?
